reviewText:
Fun game, not perfect, but worth checking out.

Gameplay: : 3.5/5

The game is rather simple for a trading card game, but there are many strategies that are viable for non-competitive modes. Unfortunately, the gameplay is not perfectly balanced, leaving some strategies much easier to use than others; however, despite some strategies being better, it is still fun making various decks to fight with.

Unlike many recent card games, this game does not have an automatic battle mode where you simply play the cards and the game decides on the moves. Instead, you are in charge of many different aspects from whether a card attacks or uses a skill to even what you attack. In a defense state, you have little control if a card is attacked directly, but if the player is attacked, you may choose to defend with a specific card or not at all.

Unfortunately, due to how defending works, it requires players to essentially know every card and with the ability to upgrade, this may become even more difficult.

Story: 3/5

This game has a rather simple story, you are part of an organization that is fighting to maintain the balance between three warring factions. Of course, your actions are supposed to be neutral with no favorites, but as can be expected, being neutral and unbiased all the time can be rather difficult.

Unfortunately, a large portion of the game is tied to the story with several unlocks and rewards being tied to story mode. That said, one may come to think of story mode as a long tutorial, which while somewhat interesting, it can feel tedious when the player wants to move onto other modes.

Fortunately for players who do enjoy story mode, certain story mode battles have mechanics that will rarely be seen elsewhere.

Graphics/Audio: 2.5/5

Graphically, the game has a decent resolution, but is limited as is apparent if viewed in full screen mode with a higher resolution monitor. As this game was originally for the Vita, this can be understandable. Fortunately, the game's graphics are still decent despite the limited resolution. It should also be noted that while the game defaults to a censored state, the game features an uncensored option for those who prefer the original art.

There are two noticeable issues with the graphics, first is that the game defaults to window mode when it starts instead of remember the last state, which combined with having to right click to access full screen mode may be annoying to some. The second issue is the more limited FPS, which players who are used to PC's higher FPS may find annoying. Unfortunately, this is unlikely to change due to animations, which would look odd at a different FPS.

Some players have noted FPS drops, this may be system dependent or a side effect of battle animations.

The audio quality is decent for the game with voice acting and music to accompany the game. While nothing especially impressive, it is decent enough.

Play Time/Replayability: 3/5

While much of the replayability of the offline game modes will be based on farming for gold in order to acquire better gear, the game can be a nice and calming to play. Story mode replayability will be primarily based on players who want a more static set of battles. Dungeon battles vary by the day, though there is still a limited amount of variety. PVC, or Player Vs Computer, battles are more randomized and can provide a decent amount of replayability. Challenge mode changes each week and players can try to make decks to get the best scores.

The majority of the replayability will be in online battles where players may form strategies to counter each other and fight in a more intelligent manner.

Final Score: 3.5/5

This game is worth trying out, especially when on sale. While it won't be a game of the year, it is fun and calming to play.

====

Notes:
This review is based on a beta build and focuses on offline mode. The reviewer beta tested the game; however, this review is the reviewer's own and not that of any company or outside organization.

In order to change to uncensored mode, go to your menu->configuration-> Card Type: Infinita

Unlike the original, there are no microtransactions. There may be DLC in the future, but you can obtain everything through the weekly rewards, gold shop (gold is in-game currency), PvC, PvP, or Dungeons. Some cards can be obtained in multiple ways.

The inability to play offline has been somewhat resolved, hopefully they will add a patch to make it so that you can do dungeons offline.

reviewText: Fun card game with fairly minimal strategy, nice artwork and an interesting evolve system. It's pretty much exactly what I expected it to be for the price. There are no microtransactions and the game by default starts censored, although the uncensored version really isn't that bad and I'm not sure why anyone would complain.\n\nAll in all it's pretty much exactly what it looks like and if you want a cheap card game to waste some time it's not bad.

reviewText:
Instantly purchased this for original uncensored art, which in itself is worth more than gold.

The major drawback of this title is that it hasn't really spent any effort on the user interface. You get a chat box for dialogue, and a menu button to access everything the game doesn't do automatically. It is not a big deal, but it differs from all modern games that integrate your game choices into the game world.

Something that is not obvious from start is that you can go home" and the game checks all your achievements and hand you bonuses. I assumed at first it was some kind of "restart the dungeon" option first and just tested it before I was supposed to quit. From home you can reach other modes (if unlocked) in addition to the default story mode.

I actually didn't find any quit button
date: so I just closed the game.\n\nEven with these minor issues
recommended: the game is alright as a card game visual novel. Voices are nice
voteText: and the card game is not too advanced (yet at least). You kind of get what you pay for. Nothing impressive
helpfulPercent: but a game that will suit most people who enjoy cards

reviewText:
This game is good, I really enjoy it, and it's a non-microtransactions card game.
The game still needs many improvements. But the devs are amazing, quick response and helpful. The game is regularly update with new features.
Pros:
- Addictive gameplay
- Full voice
- Non-microtransactions (no pay-to-win)
- Good arts with different style.
- There are many features to spend your time.
- Support is good.
- New updates come regularly.
- Offline mode is now available.
Cons:
- PvP is broken, and needs remake.
- NSFW ( You probably dont want your boss to see your naked loli cards xD )
- The drag animation is not smooth.
- Dont have Co-op mode.
- Dont have trading cards ( may come in future according to the devs)
I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Not really much of a review writer, but since I do enjoy this game and it has so little reviews, I feel a bit bad for it.

Honestly, it's a pretty simple strategy as far as some other card games go, BUT, the developers are still working on adding some more of the harder content still. Out of the 600+ cards the game has, I want to say as of May 2nd, you are currently able to collect maybe 300, 350. Which, honestly is fine right now, since it might be a little too overwhelming to have all that content. Think of a classic freemium game, now remove any timers and cooldowns, and no real money transcations.

Some cards are obviously more useful than others, and maybe you'll find the team you primarly use has some of the same cards no matter what type of deck you face. But the balance issues are fine. Because treat this game mostly as a single player game, since currently multiplayer is pretty empty. It's actually more efficient to go to the discussion page of the game and just request a match, or if you have a certain item, get a copy of one of that player's cards.

The art is what you see. If you ever wanted to see angels, dragons, yokai, monsters, lovecraftian horrors, and robots reimagined as anime girls, well, this is probably your best bet.

Interface is a little bad. It's exclusively clicking. Hopefully they add in the addition of hotkeys. What other minor issues the game has are being worked on by the devs, and they seem to be pretty on top of things.

OVERALL  if you like anime art, collecting cards, and want a nice little time waster that employs things like daily dungeons and weekly boss challenge fights, this game would be right up your alley.

reviewText:
This is a port of an old (2014) f2p VITA game, localized and adapted to remove IAPs so they can sell it to you for a one time fee instead.
Keep this in mind because it is heavily reflected on the production values of the game.

Pros :
+Simple but addictive TCG gameplay
+Fully voiced story (JP only) with VN-like presentation
+No censorship (remember to turn on Infinita" mode on options).
+A decent length story mode
+Some extra modes to keep you playing after you're done with that
date: or to strengthen your deck if you struggle with story.\n+Online versus (though be sure you got a friend to play with
recommended:
because pubs are pretty much non-existent).

Cons :
-Clunky mouse-only interface
-If you have card animations on
hoursPlayed: you'll see FPS drops when the cards "fight"\n-The story is nothing special and for the most part is one shallow excuse after another to have card battles.\n-Most of the non-story modes require a server side connection
voteText: which means they'll not work offline and will eventually die.\n-The art of the cards is very hit and miss.\n-Quality aside
helpfulPercent: each card is supposed to have 3 levels of evolution with 3 different illustrations. For a lot of them
votesHelpful: the devs cheaped out and reused the same base artwork but mirrored or recolored.\n-The VA work is very amateurish. Still acceptable for the most part (except for Cecile)
votesTotal: but don't expect any big name seiyuu here because this game has none.\n-This game is old
votesFunny: which means whatever content exists for it is already done and no more is being produced. Worryingly
commentsCount: despite that not all of the content has been ported yet. We got 10 chapters of story with an ending
column16: but we're still missing  an extra 5 story chapters
column17: several cards and some other things pertaining to the non-story modes. With this being such a niche game with barely any community presence
column18:
one has to wonder if the publisher is even gonna bother bringing all that missing content.


Buy if you like card games and lewd
column19: and want to support no-censorship localizations with JP voices
column20: just don't expect high production values."

reviewText: I used to play yu-gi-oh on my PSP alot from time to time and I love it alot but I'm not going to compare this game to yu-gi-oh as this game is fun and unique in it's own ways. Eternal Destiny is a casual non complicated card battle game which allow you to understand how to play this game within seconds without killing too much of your brain cells though sometime enemies are quite challenging. Card games is always like a drug to me, the moment when you open up a booster pack and happened to get a rare or ultra rare cards you will want to open more basically it's full of surprises. I will definitely recommend this game to all the card battle lovers.

reviewText:
This is actually the first card game I've ever purchased.  I like anime and the game seemed like it would be fun and it is.  After playing hours of high stress games, this feels like a healing moment.

The dev was kind enough to bring back original content and not cave to the noisy minority who wouldn't buy his game anyway.  I salute you.

I haven't come anywhere near finishing this game and I'm already ready to cough up money for DLC.  I hope you add  more content in the future and thanks for making this game.

reviewText: If you like deck building games like Monster Monpiece (PSVita) and Culdcept (PS2) Culdcept Saga (Xbox 360), you will almost assuredly like this game.  It's not as complex as the aforementioned titles, nor is the art work as detailed (it is still very good though), however, for ten dollars you could not find better on Steam.  Support this game!

reviewText:
The game is somewhat fun, although it's based on luck (who gets to attack first, who has better field bonuses) and who has stronger cards, any sort of strategy comes in last.

The major problems with this game, however, are multiplayer and the dungeon mechanic.

PvP has been dead since launch, can't find an opponent no matter the time of day, only have been able to find someone after a new function has been implemented, but next day it's dead again. Maybe let us set an AI deck, which would be used when we're not online.

The whole dungeon mechanic is redundant, not fun and simply a waste of time - click several hundred times, each time watching a slow progress bar animation to fight 5-10 enemies. What could take 10-20 minutes takes an hour+ and rapid clicking to make the progress as fast as possible bears the risk of misclicking capture buttons and missing out on cards. I would suggest making progress automatic, with faster/toggleable animation and stopping only at events/bosses.
